comment._content: Glenna Smith Tinnin is mentioned in passing in the NY Times as being active in the women's suffrage movement. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C00E2DC143AE6...

comment.author: 21001715@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Standing portraits, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: Mrs. Tinnin is mentioned on page 105 of "The History of Woman Suffrage" (free here at Google Books.) She is cited as the first chairman of the Equal Franchise League, founded in 1914 as The Woman Suffrage Council. There are aslo a few Internet references to her as co-author of a religious play called "One Night in Bethlehem" published in 1925. More interesting to fans of the Bain Collection, Glenna Tinnin was, according to an article in a short-lived magazine called "National Waterways" (free here from Google Books,) the "...originator and designer of the Pageant-Procession...." which took place in Washington D.C. the day before Woodrow Wilson's inauguration in 1913 (article begins on page 210.) The Suffrage Pageant is the subject of several Bain photos, as is the parade. The article mentions several other women involved in the Pageant who are also subjects of various Bain photos, including our old friends Inez Milholland, Florence Noyes, Hedwig Reicher, and Mrs. Owens and Mrs. Moore. Small photos of various Pageant participants in costume accompany the article. I suspect that many of those photos are lurking in the Bain Collection, and might appear here in the LOC photostream someday.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I started a Wikipedia entry for her, and all are welcome to add information there: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glenna_Smith_Tinnin Just ask, if you need to know how to edit Wikipedia.

comment.author: 25308510@N08
comment._content: Tarnation. I just referenced your Wikipedia article in another picture without knowing how fresh the info was. I did add a quote that google kept popping up in part or whole but do not have any further info.

comment.author: 25308510@N08
30085166@N00
comment._content: I didn't even notice the identification conflict between the photo here and the same one in the National Waterways article. Mrs. Tinnin and Miss Wilson were the same age, so we wouldn't be able to tell them apart that way (there's a brief biographical entry for Flora Wilson on page 891 of "Woman's Who's who of America" published in 1914- also free at Google Books.) In the photo of Mrs. Tinnin on page 210 of the National Waterways book she's wearing a hat, and I'm unable to determine if she's the same woman in costume as Justice in the page 211 photo (and here.) However, the Justice photo and the sitting portrait do look like the same person, so if the Bain collection mislabeled one, it must have mislabeled both. Unfortunately, I can't find any other photos identified as Flora Wilson anywhere on the Internet for a comparison, nor can I find any photos identified as Mrs. Tinnin, other than the two in the Bain Collection and the one at the top of the National Waterways article. Another puzzle to be solved.

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: I think this is, in fact, Mrs. Tinnin (not Miss Wilson). In looking through Prints and Photographs Division photographs that are not digitized, I was able to find another portrait of Mrs. Tinnin--same features (though the person who had recorded the copyright deposit photograph in 1913 wrote the name as "Tinnan, Mrs. Glenda S."!). I also found a photograph of Flora Wilson in Prints and Photographs Division files, and another portrait of her is featured in the Washington Post (March 5, 1909, p. 5). Miss Wilson had a somewhat rounder face, less deep-set eyes, and differently shaped eyebrows. Which is not to say that the labeling on the suffrage parade/pageant photos is always accurate. See the title and notes for this photo from the 1913 pageant regarding the identity of the symbol and the individual playing her: hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/ppmsc.00032 The 1913 suffrage parade was the subject of an essay featured on the Library of Congress Web site as part of "American Women: A Gateway to Library of Congress Resources for the Study of Women's History and Culture in the United States". The essay highlights multiple Library of Congress collection materials that shed light on the parade and the planning that preceded it: memory.loc.gov/ammem/awhhtml/aw01e/aw01e.html It's also interesting to note that Mrs. Tinnin apparently continued to compose pageants and plays into the 1920s--see this play notice from the University of Iowa's Redpath Chautauqua Collection: hdl.loc.gov/loc.award/iauchau./ogle/2 Thanks, all, for turning up connections to other photos and sources on the Web!

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
NY Times obituary listings for 25 March 1945:

"Word was received here last night of the death yesterday of Mrs. Glenna Smith Tinnin at a sanitarium in Chestnut Hill, Mass. She formerly lived at the Hotel Wellington, this city, and in Washington, D. C. Mrs. Tinnin was an organizer of the National Junior Theatre which gave performances at the Alvin Theatre here in 1931, and earlier, in Philadelphia, Boston, and Brooklyn. She directed the woman suffrage pageant in Washington in 1913."
